Literature Review: Cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) have emerged as crucial players in the tumor microenvironment, particularly in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). This literature review aims to explore the current understanding of CAFs in PDAC, focusing on their origin, heterogeneity, and functional roles.CAFs are a prominent component of the PDAC tumor microenvironment, often outnumbering cancer cells themselves. The origin of these cells has been a subject of intense research. Traditionally, pancreatic stellate cells (PSCs) were considered the primary source of CAFs in PDAC. However, recent studies have challenged this notion, suggesting a more complex picture. Öhlund et al. (2017) demonstrated that CAFs in PDAC exhibit significant heterogeneity, with distinct subpopulations arising from different cellular origins. This finding has led to a paradigm shift in our understanding of CAF development.The heterogeneity of CAFs extends beyond their origin to their gene expression profiles. Elyada et al. (2019) identified three distinct CAF subpopulations in PDAC: myofibroblastic CAFs (myCAFs), inflammatory CAFs (iCAFs), and antigen-presenting CAFs (apCAFs). Each subpopulation exhibits unique gene expression patterns and functional characteristics, contributing to the complexity of the tumor microenvironment.One of the primary functions of CAFs in PDAC is the deposition of extracellular matrix (ECM) components. This extensive ECM deposition leads to the characteristic desmoplastic reaction observed in PDAC, which has significant implications for tumor progression and therapy resistance. Provenzano et al. (2012) demonstrated that the dense ECM created by CAFs contributes to elevated interstitial fluid pressure within the tumor, impeding drug delivery and potentially promoting cancer cell survival.Beyond ECM production, CAFs play a crucial role in supporting cancer cell growth and survival. Sousa et al. (2016) showed that CAFs act as 'feeder' cells for cancer cells, providing essential metabolites and growth factors. This metabolic support is particularly important in the nutrient-poor environment characteristic of PDAC. The study highlighted the complex metabolic interplay between CAFs and cancer cells, suggesting potential therapeutic targets in this interaction.The impact of CAFs on the immune system within the tumor microenvironment has gained increasing attention. Feig et al. (2013) demonstrated that CAFs in PDAC contribute to an immunosuppressive environment by secreting factors that inhibit T cell infiltration and activation. This finding underscores the potential of targeting CAFs as a strategy to enhance immunotherapy efficacy in PDAC.Despite the apparent pro-tumorigenic functions of CAFs, attempts to target this cell population therapeutically have yielded mixed results. Özdemir et al. (2014) showed that complete depletion of α-smooth muscle actin (αSMA)-positive CAFs in a mouse model of PDAC led to more aggressive tumors with reduced survival. This unexpected outcome highlights the complex and potentially context-dependent roles of CAFs in tumor progression.Recent research has focused on understanding the drivers of CAF heterogeneity and function. Biffi et al. (2019) identified IL-1 and TGF-β signaling as key factors in determining CAF subtype specification in PDAC. This finding provides insight into the molecular mechanisms underlying CAF heterogeneity and suggests potential avenues for selective targeting of specific CAF subpopulations.The interaction between CAFs and other components of the tumor microenvironment, such as the vasculature, has also been explored. Rhim et al. (2014) demonstrated that CAFs contribute to the hypovascular nature of PDAC through the production of angiostatic factors. This vascular dysfunction further exacerbates the nutrient-poor, hypoxic environment characteristic of PDAC.As our understanding of CAFs in PDAC continues to evolve, new therapeutic strategies are being explored. Vennin et al. (2019) showed that targeting the mechanical properties of the ECM produced by CAFs could improve drug delivery and enhance the efficacy of chemotherapy in PDAC models. This approach represents a novel strategy for indirectly modulating CAF function in PDAC.In conclusion, the study of CAFs in PDAC has revealed a complex and heterogeneous cell population with diverse origins, gene expression profiles, and functional roles. While CAFs contribute to many aspects of PDAC progression, including ECM deposition, metabolic support of cancer cells, and immunosuppression, their functions appear to be context-dependent. Future research should focus on unraveling the drivers of CAF heterogeneity and developing targeted approaches to modulate specific CAF subpopulations or functions. Such strategies may hold the key to more effective combination therapies for this challenging malignancy.
